prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Possibility of settlement

para.paratext: The Panel has declined to hold up transfer because of the possibility of settlement, even a global settlement that might resolve all cases.[1] In In re Managed Care, the Panel distinguished earlier cases where it had confronted a completed settlement, a situation that may well render transfer moot.[2] Where there are settlements pending that would resolve the actions, the Panel may be more likely to deny transfer.[3] Indeed, where a settlement is pending, the Panel has expressed the view that centralization of the litigation may actually delay the reaching of a final settlement.[4] If the Panel reaches the conclusion that a centralization order would interfere with the prospects of finalizing a pending settlement, it is certainly likely to deny transfer.[5] The Panel has also considered the pendency of a settlement in selecting the transferee district favoring transfer to the court where the settlement is pending.[6]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

In re: Gold King Mine Release in San Juan County, Colorado, on August 5, 2015, 291 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (Panel finds transfer should have no impact on settlement discussions); In re Synthroid Marketing Litigation, 1997 WL 564075 (N.D. Cal. 1997); In re Banc of America Inv. Services, Inc., 466 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Managed Care Litigation, 246 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Lease Oil Antitrust Litigation No. II, 48 F. Supp. 2d 699 (S.D. Tex. 1998) (transferee court notes that Panel had transferred action in which a global settlement had been reached in one of the transferor courts); In re Synthroid Marketing Litigation, 1997 WL 564075 (N.D. Cal. 1997) (although reported as a decision of the Northern District of California, this is clearly a Panel decision); In re Viatron Computer Systems, 462 F. Supp. 382 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Armored Car Antitrust Litigation, 462 F. Supp. 394 (J.P.M.L. 1978)

In re Managed Care Litigation, 246 F. Supp. 2d 1363, 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2003), distinguishing In re Charles Schwab & Co. “Best Execution” Securities Litigation, 2000 U.S. Dist LEXIS 5105 (J.P.M.L. Apr. 14, 2000).

In re: Healthtap Inc. Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 26 F. Supp. 3d 1389 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: JPMorgan Chase & Co. Fair Labor Standards ACT (FLSA) Litigation, 729 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010) (transfer denied despite initial agreement because of intervening settlement agreement); In re: Checking Account Overdraft Litigation, 715 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).

In re Behr Deckover Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 285 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018); In re Wells Fargo Fraudulent Account Opening Litigation, 282 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).

See In re: JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., Mortg. Corp. Force-Placed Hazard Ins. Litigation, 959 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013);In re: Building Products of Canada Corp. Organic Shingles Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012);In re: Power Balance, LLC, Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 777 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
See, e.g., In re: Enfamil Lipil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
